// towards their goal
    // ignore entries for tables that do not exist in zookeeper

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

    // if we are shutting down all the tabletservers, we have to do it in order
                // log.info("Current servers " + currentTServers.keySet());
                // maybe it's a finishing migration
                    // if destination is still good, assign it
                        // get rid of this migration
                // Send another reminder
                // log.info("Current servers " + currentTServers.keySet());

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// towards their goal
    // ignore entries for tables that do not exist in zookeeper
    // Don't overwhelm the tablet servers with work
    // Always follow through with assignments
    // if we are shutting down all the tabletservers, we have to do it in order
                // log.info("Current servers " + currentTServers.keySet());
                // maybe it's a finishing migration
                    // if destination is still good, assign it
                        // get rid of this migration
                // Send another reminder
                // log.info("Current servers " + currentTServers.keySet());

File: server/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/server/master/Master.java
Line: 1308

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// towards their goal
    // ignore entries for tables that do not exist in zookeeper
    // Don't overwhelm the tablet servers with work
    // Always follow through with assignments
    // if we are shutting down all the tabletservers, we have to do it in order
                // log.info("Current servers " + currentTServers.keySet());
                // maybe it's a finishing migration
                    // if destination is still good, assign it
                        // get rid of this migration
                // Send another reminder

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

Line: 3070

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

    // ignore entries for tables that do not exist in zookeeper

                // maybe it's a finishing migration
                    // if destination is still good, assign it
                        // get rid of this migration
                // Send another reminder
                // log.info("Current servers " + currentTServers.keySet());

File: server/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/server/master/Master.java
Line: 1292

// file was created or imported after we obtained the first an last keys... there
// are a few options here... throw an exception which will cause the compaction to
// retry and also cause ugly error message that the admin has to ignore... could
// go get the first and last key, but this code is called while the tablet lock
// is held... or just compact the file....

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// towards their goal
    // ignore entries for tables that do not exist in zookeeper
    // Don't overwhelm the tablet servers with work
    // Always follow through with assignments
    // if we are shutting down all the tabletservers, we have to do it in order
                // log.info("Current servers " + currentTServers.keySet());
                // maybe it's a finishing migration
                    // if destination is still good, assign it
                        // get rid of this migration
                // Send another reminder
                // log.info("Current servers " + currentTServers.keySet());

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

    // ignore entries for tables that do not exist in zookeeper

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

File: examples/simple/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/examples/simple/mapreduce/bulk/BulkIngestExample.java
Line: 82

    // ignore entries for tables that do not exist in zookeeper

    // if we are shutting down all the tabletservers, we have to do it in order
                // log.info("Current servers " + currentTServers.keySet());
                // maybe it's a finishing migration
                    // if destination is still good, assign it
                        // get rid of this migration
                // Send another reminder
                // log.info("Current servers " + currentTServers.keySet());

File: server/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/server/master/Master.java
Line: 1308

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

    // Don't overwhelm the tablet servers with work

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// to let accumulo set the time

                // maybe it's a finishing migration
                    // if destination is still good, assign it
                        // get rid of this migration
                // Send another reminder
                // log.info("Current servers " + currentTServers.keySet());

Line: 137

// is held... or just compact the file....

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// to let accumulo set the time

// towards their goal
    // ignore entries for tables that do not exist in zookeeper
    // Don't overwhelm the tablet servers with work
    // Always follow through with assignments
    // if we are shutting down all the tabletservers, we have to do it in order
                // log.info("Current servers " + currentTServers.keySet());
                // maybe it's a finishing migration
                    // if destination is still good, assign it
                        // get rid of this migration
                // Send another reminder
                // log.info("Current servers " + currentTServers.keySet());

// go get the first and last key, but this code is called while the tablet lock

Line: 3073

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

    // ignore entries for tables that do not exist in zookeeper

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

    // if we are shutting down all the tabletservers, we have to do it in order
                // log.info("Current servers " + currentTServers.keySet());
                // maybe it's a finishing migration
                    // if destination is still good, assign it
                        // get rid of this migration
                // Send another reminder
                // log.info("Current servers " + currentTServers.keySet());

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

                    // if destination is still good, assign it
                        // get rid of this migration
                // Send another reminder

// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// retry and also cause ugly error message that the admin has to ignore... could
// go get the first and last key, but this code is called while the tablet lock
// is held... or just compact the file....

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

    // ignore entries for tables that do not exist in zookeeper

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// towards their goal
    // ignore entries for tables that do not exist in zookeeper
    // Don't overwhelm the tablet servers with work
    // Always follow through with assignments
    // if we are shutting down all the tabletservers, we have to do it in order
                // log.info("Current servers " + currentTServers.keySet());
                // maybe it's a finishing migration
                    // if destination is still good, assign it
                        // get rid of this migration

// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// The purpose of this watcher is a hack. It forces the creation on a new zoocache instead

// would update less, causing the configuration update count to changes less.

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// towards their goal
    // ignore entries for tables that do not exist in zookeeper
    // Don't overwhelm the tablet servers with work
    // Always follow through with assignments
    // if we are shutting down all the tabletservers, we have to do it in order
                // log.info("Current servers " + currentTServers.keySet());
                // maybe it's a finishing migration
                    // if destination is still good, assign it

// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// The purpose of this watcher is a hack. It forces the creation on a new zoocache instead
// of using a shared one. This was done so that the zoocache
// would update less, causing the configuration update count to changes less.

// The purpose of this watcher is a hack. It forces the creation on a new zoocache instead

// would update less, causing the configuration update count to changes less.

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is

// The purpose of this watcher is a hack. It forces the creation on a new zoocache instead
// of using a shared one. This was done so that the zoocache
// would update less, causing the configuration update count to changes less.

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// The purpose of this watcher is a hack. It forces the creation on a new zoocache instead
// of using a shared one. This was done so that the zoocache
// would update less, causing the configuration update count to changes less.

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// go get the first and last key, but this code is called while the tablet lock
// is held... or just compact the file....

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is

// The purpose of this watcher is a hack. It forces the creation on a new zoocache instead

// would update less, causing the configuration update count to changes less.

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// retry and also cause ugly error message that the admin has to ignore... could
// go get the first and last key, but this code is called while the tablet lock
// is held... or just compact the file....

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// The purpose of this watcher is a hack. It forces the creation on a new zoocache instead
// of using a shared one. This was done so that the zoocache
// would update less, causing the configuration update count to changes less.

// of using a shared one. This was done so that the zoocache
// would update less, causing the configuration update count to changes less.

Line: 57

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

File: examples/simple/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/examples/simple/mapreduce/bulk/BulkIngestExample.java
Line: 83

// wait for the tserver to give up on writing to the WAL

        // Yes, there's a tabletserver
        // Kill dfs

// The purpose of this watcher is a hack. It forces the creation on a new zoocache instead of using a shared one. This was done so that the zoocache
// would update less, causing the configuration update count to changes less.

// The purpose of this watcher is a hack. It forces the creation on a new zoocache instead
// of using a shared one. This was done so that the zoocache
// would update less, causing the configuration update count to changes less.

File: server/base/src/main/java/org/apache/accumulo/server/conf/ZooConfigurationFactory.java
Line: 57

// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// The purpose of this watcher is a hack. It forces the creation on a new zoocache instead
// of using a shared one. This was done so that the zoocache

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// The purpose of this watcher is a hack. It forces the creation on a new zoocache instead

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is

// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later
// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
// cluster or consider using logical time... one options is
// to let accumulo set the time

// The purpose of this watcher is a hack. It forces the creation on a new zoocache instead
// of using a shared one. This was done so that the zoocache
// would update less, causing the configuration update count to changes less.

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in
// accumulo if there is already an existing value with a later

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// be careful with the timestamp... if you run on a cluster
// where the time is whacked you may not see your updates in

// timestamp in accumulo... so make sure ntp is running on the
